raw_text:
Greene sets sights on world title
 
 Maurice Greene aims to wipe out the pain of losing his Olympic 100m title in Athens by winning a fourth World Championship crown this summer.
 
 He had to settle for bronze in Greece behind fellow American Justin Gatlin and Francis Obikwelu of Portugal. "It really hurts to look at that medal. It was my mistake. I lost because of the things I did," said Greene, who races in Birmingham on Friday. "It's never going to happen again. My goal - I'm going to win the worlds." Greene crossed the line just 0.02 seconds behind Gatlin, who won in 9.87 seconds in one of the closest and fastest sprints of all time. But Greene believes he lost the race and his title in the semi-finals. "In my semi-final race, I should have won the race but I was conserving energy. "That's when Francis Obikwelu came up and I took third because I didn't know he was there. "I believe that's what put me in lane seven in the final and, while I was in lane seven, I couldn't feel anything in the race.
 
 "I just felt like I was running all alone. "I believe if I was in the middle of the race I would have been able to react to people that came ahead of me." Greene was also denied Olympic gold in the 4x100m men's relay when he could not catch Britain's Mark Lewis-Francis on the final leg. The Kansas star is set to go head-to-head with Lewis-Francis again at Friday's Norwich Union Grand Prix. The pair contest the 60m, the distance over which Greene currently holds the world record of 6.39 seconds. He then has another indoor meeting in France before resuming training for the outdoor season and the task of recapturing his world title in Helsinki in August. Greene believes Gatlin will again prove the biggest threat to his ambitions in Finland. But he also admits he faces more than one rival for the world crown. "There's always someone else coming. I think when I was coming up I would say there was me and Ato (Boldon) in the young crowd," Greene said. "Now you've got about five or six young guys coming up at the same time."
llama3.2:1b: Maurice Greene is training to win his fourth World Championship title after losing a bronze medal finish in Athens by 0.02 seconds behind Justin Gatlin. He believes he lost the race and title due to conserving energy, which allowed Francis Obikwelu to take third place. Greene also had issues catching Britain's Mark Lewis-Francis on the final leg of the 4x100m relay for Olympic gold.
llama3.2:3b: Maurice Greene aims to win a fourth World Championship crown this summer after finishing bronze in Athens, where he lost to Justin Gatlin. Greene believes he should have won the 100m semi-finals but was conserving energy and didn't realize Francis Obikwelu's presence, costing him lane placement. He also wants to retake his world record in the 60m and compete with Gatlin again at the World Championships.
gemma2:2b: Maurice Greene aims to win a fourth world championship title after losing his Olympic 100m title in Athens. He attributes his loss partly to energy conservation in the semi-finals and believes a different start would have made him more competitive in the final. He will face Mark Lewis-Francis again at Friday's Norwich Union Grand Prix, including the 60m distance where Greene holds the world record. After the indoor meeting, he'll resume training before heading to Helsinki for the World Championships in August.  Greene expects Gatlin to be a strong opponent but acknowledges facing multiple competitors in his pursuit of the title.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Maurice Greene aims to win another World Championship crown this summer, after losing his Olympic 100m title by only 0.02 seconds behind Justin Gatlin and Francis Obikwelu of Portugal. Greene believes he lost the race and his title in the semi-finals, which was against American competitor Ato Boldon. He will compete again at Norwich Union Grand Prix to contest the 60m relay event with Mark Lewis-Francis, who holds the world record for the distance. Greene is facing more rivals for a World Championship crown than he did during his Olympic career.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Maurice Greene aims to win his fourth World Championship title this summer in Birmingham, following a bronze medal finish behind Gatlin and Obikwelu. He believes he lost the world championships due to poor preparation and misjudged opponents in the semi-finals, feeling alone during the final stretch. Despite not winning, he plans to compete with Mark Lewis-Francis again at the Norwich Union Grand Prix and believes his next competition will be against many others aiming for the title.
qwen2.5:3b: Maurice Greene aims to win a fourth World Championship title after his bronze medal finish in Athens. He lost his Olympic 100m gold due to a mismanaged energy conservation strategy, particularly during the semi-finals and final race. In the 4x100m relay, he missed out on an Olympic gold by failing to catch up with Mark Lewis-Francis. Greene plans to compete against Lewis-Franz again at the Norwich Union Grand Prix, where he holds a world record in the 60m event. He believes Gatlin will remain his main rival for the World Championship but acknowledges facing competition from multiple young runners as well.

Greene aims to win four World Championships this summer, aiming to replace the 100m Olympic gold medalist who lost his title in Greece with a bronze medal and a final placement of second. He was beaten by Justin Gatlin in a close sprint race, with Obikwelu joining him in third due to energy conservation. Greene believes losing the semi-final race will affect his lane placement in the final, where he felt alone and unable to react to those ahead of him. Despite losing gold in the relay, he faces multiple rivals for the world title in Helsinki in August.
tinyllama:1.1b: Greene, who lost to Gatlin in Athens by just 0.02 seconds, aims to win his fourth World Championship title and reclaim his Olympic gold medal won in Athens four years ago. He also believes that he will face multiple competitors for the world crown as there are more than one rivals for him, including former Olympic champion Ato Boladon. However, Greene also acknowledges that GaTLin will be a tough opponent.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Maurice Greene, a world-renowned track and field athlete, is currently competing in Birmingham, England for a fourth World Championship crown in the men's 100m race. Despite being one of the favorites to win, Greene faces significant competition from his peers as well as formidable opponents within himself. Gatlin, a fellow American sprinter who won an impressive bronze medal in Athens, is currently leading the field with a time of 9.87 seconds. This time last year, Gatlin had already established his dominance in this event and was considered the favorite to win the World Championship. However, it turned out that victory would not be his during the recent sprints at the European Championships in May when he was defeated by fellow American Obikwelu. Greene, on the other hand, has set his sights on winning his fourth World Championship title and reclaiming his Olympic gold medal from 2004. He believes that his defeat in Athens was due to a combination of factors, including his own perceived mistake in the semi-finals, as well as the energy conservation technique employed by Gatlin. Despite these setbacks, Greene is determined to prove that he deserves to be on top and continues to train for the world's most prestigious athletics event.

He believes he could have won his race and the gold medal if he had not conserved energy in the semi-finals and underestimated his opponents, especially Lewis-Francis, whom he is set to face at Friday's Grand Prix. He also mentions that he faces competition from other young sprinters who are challenging him for the world title in Helsinki later this year.
